title: Give a title to the pages
tests: Identify all the pages / screens making up the structure of the site or the application
verifier: Every page or screen has a title

Each title is specific and applied to the page content, and is written from the most accurate information to the most general.
example: [current page name - site name].
resultat: The page titles allow a user to know where they are in the site tree
To be effective the page title must be unique and represent the content of the page

title: Provide sections with headings
verifier: The page content is structured with headings level
The structure is adapted to the content
The headings are logically ordered
Every heading is relevant to the content that follows it
resultat: The page structure facilitates its understanding and makes it possible to optimize reading (quick reading, targeted reading)
The number of headings depends on the information density of the page. The absence of headings can be cumbersome but, conversely, an abundance of headings can be counterproductive
Level jumps, such as going from a “N” level heading straight to a “N+2” level heading, are inherently illogical and can disrupt reading
Headings guide and facilitate the reading, provided they are consistent with the content they precedee

title: Structuring data tables
verifier: Data tables are preceded by a heading; otherwise a legend is specified
Column and/or line headers indicate the nature of the data
Whenever possible, several simple tables are used instead of a complex table
In all the tables of the application, the texts are aligned to the left in the columns and the quantitative data (e.g. numeric values) are aligned to the right
In multi-line tables, a pajama or zebra effect is applied (e.g. alternate background color in one line out of 2)
Column and line headers are always displayed if a scrollbar is needed to navigate the table
For multiple-selection tables, actions that can be applied to multiple rows are grouped under the table (versus action buttons repeated on each row)
resultat: A heading or a caption makes it easier for screen reader users to find a table in a page, but more importantly to quickly understand the nature of the data presented
Column and/or line headers allow users to understand the nature of the table data
Tables are hard to parse for any user, they must be used sparingly, when there is no other solution
In a table, a text aligned to the left is easier to read; for quantitative data it's the opposite, you have to align them to the right
A background with an alternating color makes it easier to read a line in a multi-line table
If a scrollbar is needed to display the contents of the table, column and line headers must be fixed to keep them close to the data and facilitate their identification
Multi-selectable tables with identical actions for each line provide generic action buttons to ease presentation and cognitive load.

title: Set text alternatives
tests: Identify all non-text elements conveying information (images, icons, etc.)
verifier: Text alternative is specified for any non-text element conveying information

The text alternative is relevant, considering the role of the element.
  • Image link element: the target of the link
  • Image conveying information: the information conveyed by the image
  • Image containing text: the text shown in the image
  • Complex image (diagrams, graphs, etc.): the description of the image by a text, either directly in the page, or accessible via a link close to the image
  • Decorative image: an empty text alternative
The functional icons and pictograms are explicit and have a relevant text alternative; if necessary, a tooltip with the information is also provided in addition
resultat: A text alternative (ALT attribute of the images) makes it possible to describe to users having access only to textual content any non-text informative element
The text alternative must describe the purpose or function of the element to be usable
Icons and pictograms with a function must be understandable and have a text alternative describing their exact function. An additional tooltip may be useful to visually impaired users

title: Make audio, video and animation tracks accessible
tests: Identify the audio, video and animation contents of the site or application
The article “Making videos, animations or audios accessible” presents the complete definitions and recommendations on this subject
verify: For all audio and video content, a complete transcript (text containing all the visual and auditory information) is present on the page or accessible via a link nearby
All videos are subtitled, subtitles are provided in text format and are not embedded directly into the video
Audio description is available for videos presenting information in visual form
No audio or video track will automatically start loading a page
“Pause”, “playback” and “volume control” controls are associated with every audio and video track,
Videos do not flash fast (no more than 3 flashes per second)
resultat: In order to allow any user who cannot hear or see to have access to the information, any audio or video track must be accompanied by a complete transcription in the form of text, located near the element to be described, or made available via a link
Subtitles allow to convey all the information of the soundtrack. They must be provided in text format so they can be adapted to the needs of users (color, size, etc.)
An audio description describes the information conveyed only by the image, thus completing the audio for, for example, visually impaired users
Playing an audio or video track must always be done at the request of the user, they must have control over it
Any audio or video track can be interrupted and paused in order to leave the choice to the user; its volume must be adjustable
A quick flash in a video can trigger disorders such as epileptic seizures

title: Avoid captchas
verifier: To solve the captcha, users have the choice between an audio or visual system

If the captcha is only audio or only visual, an alternative is present in the form of a logical test (a question whose answer is obvious, a simple mathematical test, etc.) Otherwise, another solution of access to the functionality secured by the captcha is proposed
resultat: Private users of the visual information must be able to solve the captcha by an audio system, in the same way those deprived of the auditory information must be able to solve it visually
Captchas based on a single resolution system must offer an alternative to allow the greatest number of users to have access to it

title: Ensuring a sufficient contrast between text and background
tests: Examine Graphics Mockups Using the Color Contrast Analyzer Tool
verifier:
The contrast between the text (or text as an image) and the background color is as follows:
  • 4.5: 1 minimum for text size less than 24px CSS and 19px CSS in bold
  • 3:1 is sufficient for a text size greater than 24px CSS and 19px CSS in bold
Any graphical object conveying information and any interactive component and its states respects the 3: 1 ratio
resultat: To be legible a text (or text as an image) must be sufficiently contrasted with the background

It is the same for the contrast of graphical objects conveying information (example: icons, diagram), interactive components (example: outline of an input field) and its states (example: hovering or on focus)
exception:
This recommendation does not apply in the following cases:
  • if the image is a logo
  • if a text, such as a label or an array of data, provides the same information as the icon or graphic
  • if the lack of contrast in the image does not preclude understanding of the content or its function
  • if the components are inactive

title: Do not use color or other sensory characteristics as the only source of information
tests: Identify the elements using color to convey information
Identify the elements using sensory data of position, size or sound type, to transmit information
verifier: Color is not the only way to convey information
The information transmitted by a sensory data can also be obtained by an explicit text
resultat: The color may not be perceived by a user, that is why any information transmitted by a color must also be conveyed by an explicit text or a visually explicit information (example: icons of different forms)
The same is true of sensory indications such as shape, positioning in space or sound, all must be accompanied by an alternative in the form of a text

title: Labelling links and buttons concisely and unequivocally
tests: List all links, buttons and navigation items
verifier: Any link, button or navigation item with the same function is identically labelled
Each wording is relevant to the function it describes outside of any visual context,
The size of a label is short (<80 characters)
Image-based links and buttons have text alternative
resultat: To avoid confusion, links, buttons and navigation items with the same label must point to the same target, or perform the same action
A link or a button must be able to be understood without the visual context of the page via its label.
For more efficiency, the action button titles start with an explicit action verb (eg 'print' versus 'print')
In order lighten the cognitive load of users, the labels of the links and buttons are short (maximum size recommended: 80 characters)
A link or button based on an image or icon, respects image recommendations

title: Avoid the dialogs and the opening of new windows
verifier: The opening of any new window or dialog is justified,
The texts contained in the dialog boxes are concise and explicit
The user is notified when an action may open of a new window or tab
resultat:
Any opening of windows or dialog boxes (pop-in) causes a change of context that can disturb the user.
The use of dialogue boxes must be reserved for the presentation of information or actions that require attention. immediate users.
A new window is justified for the opening of an office document (eg PDF), for the display of complementary contextual information (eg instruction to fill a form), or when the user connected to a secure area, opens a page outside the secured zone
The dialogs allow you to interact with the user, for example, to alert him or ask him for confirmation, messages must be short and clear

In order not to surprise the user, the opening of a new window must first be announced, so that he can choose not to trigger the event. In a specification document or on the models, the label of the triggers is described as: [link target] + (new window), for exemple: 'Orange.com (new window)'

title: Providing skip links
verifier: Skip links are present as the first interactive element of the page. These links redirect to the main regions of the page (navigation, main content, footer, etc.)
The number of avoidance links and their destination are relevant to the density of the content (1 to 6 links maximum)
resultat:
Skip links are useful shortcuts for all users who can not use a mouse (keyboard user or screen reader) or have only a partial view of the screen (screen magnifier user).
They avoid, for example, to a keyboard user, having to focus all the items of the main menu to reach the main content of the page

The implementation of the links must take into account the level of difficulty of access to information and the structure of the page. Heavy content pages have a maximum of 6 avoidance links, against 1 link minimum for a classic page (light content, reduced main menu, etc.) Moreover, it is useless to propose a shortcut 'go to main content', if the number of elements preceding the content is limited

title: Ensuring that the user keeps control of the system during interactions
tests: Examine user paths and associated specifications
verifier: Whatever the user paths, only the actions requested by the user are executed and the user can always interrupt them.The user controls the system
resultat:
The user must control the system and not the other way around.
It's even more important, if the user does not see what is happening on the screen, it can quickly be lost, if the system takes control without notifying it. So, the validation of a form must not be automatic but requires an explicit activation of a button by the user. In the same way, the update of a form an application or the download of a new element must be done with the agreement of the user

title: Allow the user to control animations
tests: Identify any content intended to be in motion, updated automatically, flashing or scrolling for more than 5 seconds
verifier: The animations (including video and audio) are paused when the page loads
If an animation is moving when the page loads, a mechanism is then present to allow the user to stop it, pause it or hide it
No item on the page blinks fast or generates flashes of more than 3 repetitions per second
resultat: Moving elements disrupt some users and make reading difficult (especially visually impaired, epileptic, or having attention problems), so they should be paused on page load
If animations are in automatic reading, it is essential to be able to stop or hide them
Flashes or any flashing element have a strong impact on epileptic users, and will also disrupt the attention of all users

title: Explicitly locate the page in the site and provide several ways to access it
verifier:
In all pages, at least 2 of the mechanisms listed below are present:
  • a main navigation menu, showing the current position of the user
  • a sitemap
  • a search mechanism
  • a list of links to navigate through the whole site
In the main navigation menu, the active item is accompanied by a visual proof
The label of each topic, tab, menu item is identical to the title of the page to which it refers
resultat: Depending on the user (capabilities, materials, preferences, etc.), it may be easier to use either mechanism. Good practices recommend giving the user a choice of at least 2 mechanisms to locate and access a page or content in the site

So that the user always knows where he is, in the global navigation menu, the active page is accompanied by a visual indication.This proof should not be based solely on the color. the menu is underlined

In order to confirm to the user after an action that it is in the right place, the title of the page must be consistent with the label of the starting point (name of the link, the heading or the item of menu)

title: Reassure the user with contextual messages
verifier:
When the system is working (for example, take control), check that the user is warned:
  • by a waiting icon for a delay between 2 and 6 seconds
  • by a progress bar beyond 6 seconds, completed with an encrypted indication and / or a description of the current task
  • by an infinite progress bar if the time is unknown
resultat: The user must be informed of any system operation taking more than 3 seconds in order to be reassured and to avoid erroneous actions

title: Allow navigation only keyboard
verifier: The interactive components of the application are based on native HTML interactive elements
Complex interactive components provide a keyboard equivalent to all mouse behaviors
An alternative solution to the keyboard is proposed to any specific interaction with the mouse (drag-and-drop, menu appearing at the right click, etc.)
resultat: The native HTML interactive elements are by default usable with a keyboard and well known by users, so a user without a mouse will not be blocked to use the application only on the keyboard
Complex interactive components (eg drop-down menu) not based on native elements only, must be usable with the keyboard

Alternative solutions must be offered to any user who can not use a mouse, so a feature based on a specific interaction with the mouse, must also be usable by a means compatible with a keyboard navigation

title: Ensure a sufficiant visibility of the focus
tests: Identify interactive elements (links, buttons, form elements, interactive components)
verifier: The native visualization of the keyboard focus proposed by the browser is present and visible for all the interactive elements
The outline (the border that makes visible the element that has the focus) has a thickness greater than 1 px
The outline has a contrast level of at least 3:1, regardless of the background color
resultat: The highlighting of the elements receiving the focus, allows keyboard users to find their way
The native thickness of the outline is not sufficient to ensure good visibility, so it needs to be increased
In the same way, the default outline does not always provide sufficient contrast depending on the background color, so the color of the outline has to be adjusted according to the background color.

title: Make sure the focus order is logical
tests: Identify interactive elements (links, buttons, form elements, interactive components)
verifier: The location of the elements on the screen respects a reading order and logical navigation (from the most important to the least important, from top to bottom of the screen)
Visually, elements of the same nature are grouped, respecting the logic of reading and navigation
resultat: The the focus order during a keyboard navigation must be intuitive for the users, so the interactive elements must be positioned on the screen in a logical way to avoid unintentional movements of the viewport

It may be necessary to group elements of the same kind in the same space, in order to facilitate understanding. The order of navigation in a group and the positioning of the groups in the overall course must be logical

title: Use relative sizes to make the web responsive
tests: Examine the specifications associated with wireframes and graphic mockups
verifier: No specification imposes a fixed maximum value (px (pixel), mm (millimeters), cm (centimeters), in (inches), pt (points is 1/72 of an inch) or pc (picas is 12 points)) both for the width and height of a text container.If a fixed width is set, then the height will have no fixed value
Conversely, a minimum value and / or values ​​in relative units are allowed
If the site is adaptive (or responsive web design), features and information are available for the most common screen sizes (to see depending on the context of the project)
resultat: Texts contained in an element whose dimensions are defined in fixed size: (px (pixel), mm (millimeters), cm (centimeters), in (inches), pt (points is 1/72 of an inch) or pc (picas is 12 points), will be truncated during an enlargement (text zoom to 200%)
The definition of fixed maximum dimensions will also cause loss of information during an enlargement
The dimensions must be defined by minimum values ​​(min-width, min-height) or values ​​in relative units (%, em, rem), in order to ensure an enlargement of the containers whatever the level of zoom
In the case of an adaptive (or responsive) site the user can interact with the application and view all the information regardless of the size of the screen

title: Make possible the aeration of the texts
verifier: The space between the lines is equivalent to 1.5 times the size of the minimum text. If this is not the case, no specification imposes a fixed value for the line spacing
No specification imposes a fixed value for the space between two paragraphs
No specification imposes a fixed value for the spacing between letters
No specification imposes a fixed value for spacing between words
resultat: Users who are visually impaired, dyslexic or have cognitive problems have reading difficulties when the lines are too tight, they can be lost at the line break, this spacing criterion will ensure the text is always readable. Users must be able to adjust the spacing between lines to overcome their reading difficulties.To allow these adjustments, spacings should not be defined in a fixed-size unit: px (pixel), mm (millimeters), cm (centimeters), in (inches), pt (points is 1/72 of an inch) or pc (picas is 12 points)
In the same way, the space between the paragraphs must be adjustable by the user
The spacing between the letters must be adjustable by the user
The spacing between words must be adjustable by the user

title: Identify the different regions and elements of the page and ensure the coherence of the groupings
tests: Identify the main regions of the page (header, menu, etc.)
Identify the main content groups (interactive components, pop-in, etc.)
verifier: All links in text content are underlined or highlighted by visual cues, complementing the color
Information of the same nature is grouped in the same components (the same page, the same area in the page, the same menu, etc.)
The main regions of the page and groups of elements (submenu, drop-down list, etc.) are clearly identifiable visually (border, texture, colors, etc.)

A navigation system common to a group of pages is always presented in a constant way (position, graphic aspect). At the same, action buttons common to several pages (same function or action on all pages) are always positioned in the same place
resultat: Assigning to the links a different color is not enough to distinguish a link from its contents, additional visual proof is necessary for a user, not seeing the colors, the marks

Elements, data and information of the same nature and / or related semantically (e.g. navigation links) must be physically grouped to facilitate their identification and identification, for example, the logo, the title of the application and the functions cross-references (search engine-type links, choice of language) are placed on the page header Access to help or FAQ, contacts and legal notices are placed in the footer

All pages or dialogs of the same nature (e.g. form page, help page, etc.) must have the same zoning (e.g. the same organization).
For example, users of screen magnifier, not perceiving the whole of a page on their screen, must be able to easily identify the limits of the different zones of contents.

To gain efficiency and avoid errors, a navigation system common to a page group is always presented consistently (e.g. if the application includes a step bar, this bar is set to the identically and visibly on all pages throughout the process)

title: Define sensitive areas of sufficient size
verifier: The dimensions of the interactive elements (links, form elements, boutons) are sufficient (at least 44px by 44px)
resultat: A user with motor difficulties may have difficulty interacting with a touch application or using a mouse, if the interactive elements are not large enough
exception:
• Anchor / internal link to the page
  • Link inside a text
  • Link to a footnote (at the end of paragraph or phrase)
  • Icon clickable inside a text

title: Facilitating the completion of forms
verifier: Each input field is accompanied by a label
The wording is concise and explicit

Each label is positioned in the immediate vicinity of its field, and if multiple labels follow, they are left-aligned if the longest label in the list is 6 or less characters, and right-aligned otherwise
The same data does not need to be entered several times by the user
Default values ​​are offered whenever the content is predictable
The application does not offer a form that exceeds the height of a screen page
resultat: A label allows the user to understand the role of the field, the type and format of data expected
The labels of fields and buttons must be relevant and understandable by all users
The positioning of the wording must allow the user to associate it without hesitation with the field to which it refers
In order to lighten the work of the user and avoid typing errors, the identical data must be entered in one entry, with the exception of data requiring confirmation
For the same reasons, when possible, default values ​​are proposed to the user to fill a field, for example, a list of check items rather than a free entry field
To avoid long and complex forms, requiring scrolling, they must be divided into several pages, using a visual process step

title: Protecting the user from errors in forms
verifier: If the application has multiple forms, fields that expect identical data have all the same label
Required fields are mentioned to users
The specific input formats are announced to users (example: date format)

Lists of selectable items use relevant inputs:
  1. radio buttons: when only one item can be selected from a list of up to 5 items
  2. drop-down lists: when a single item can be selected from a list of more than 5 items
  3. check boxes: when more than one item can to be selected.
An input control for the text fields is proposed when necessary.The mandatory fields not filled in are reported to the user, if possible, before the validation of the form
Actions, whose effect can not be canceled, can be controlled by the user.
Error or warning messages are easily identifiable and presented in a homogeneous way

The contents of the error or alert messages are relevant:
  • No generic error message like 'You have made a mistake' or 'Error 404' is not used;
  • each message explicitly describes the problem (context / origin of the error);
  • a procedure for solving the error is proposed whenever possible
resultat: For consistency and simplification, fields waiting for identical data must be identically labelled
To avoid omissions before sending the form, the mandatory fields must be reported to the user, for example by an asterisk placed at the end of the label
Some data can currently be entered in different ways (e.g. a date). To avoid typing errors, the expected format for this type of data must be specified
Radio button, check box, drop-down list are separate components each having their own role. A drop-down list allows to optimize the space (vs long radio button list)
The real-time control of the fields of a form allows the user to correct his entry as and when, and not after the submission of the form
In the interest of security, it is important to protect with a confirmation message actions that may be harmful (for example: Do you really want to delete?)

Accompany error messages, alert or help a specific icon displayed to the left of the message (for example: exclamation point for an alert message, cross in a red dot to report an error, question mark for a help message) allows the user to quickly locate them
To be useful, the error messages must be explicit, they specify in particular what error was made and, if possible, a way to correct it

title: Provide an alternative to complex gestures
verifier: All multi-pointer gestures (requiring several fingers), and / or requiring trajectories to perform an action, have an alternative requiring a single pointer (one finger)
resultat:
Some users can not perform a complex action requiring, for example, several fingers. To be accessible, this type of action must also be achieved via a simple interaction.
Example: for a zoom action on a card with a pinch of a finger, an alternative in the form of button [+] and [-] is provided

title: Allow the user to choose the orientation of the screen
verifier: The layout of all screens has been designed to allow interaction in portrait and landscape mode
resultat: Some users are forced to set the consultation mode, portrait mode or landscape mode only (tablet mounted on a wheelchair for example). It is therefore important that these users can view all the information and use all the features in the 2 orientations
